name: Lower Yosemite Fall
description: One of the favorite destinations in the park, featuring an easy hike where you can experience the mist of the falls from a foot bridge.
tips: Visit in early spring just after sunrise to capture a rainbow in the falls
The mist can spray you from the foot bridge during early spring

name: Nevada and Vernal Falls
description: A magnificently photogenic hike featuring two massive waterfalls, the Mist Trail, and the Emerald Pool lake at the top.
tips: Get slightly off the path to avoid crowds
Watch out for wet and slippery rocks
Use ND filters for long-exposure waterfall effects
Bring lens wipes and a sun hood to manage moisture from the mist

name: Vernal Falls
description: A strenuous but satisfying hike along the Mist Trail that allows you to climb to the top of both Vernal and Nevada Falls.
tips: This is an all day affair so bring extra water and camera batteries
Be prepared for a strenuous climb while hauling camera equipment

name: Glacier Point Road
description: A scenic stretch of road leading to Glacier Point, particularly the last section before the parking lot which offers views of Half Dome after a dramatic curve.
tips: Park in the lot and hike back up the road to find the curve
Look for the spot where Half Dome is framed directly in front of the road

name: El Capitan Meadow
description: Offers amazing views of the granite faces of El Capitan and Cathedral Rocks, which serve as a majestic backdrop.
tips: Best to park North of the river
Great place to wander around for different compositions

name: Horsetail Fall – Yosemite Firefall
description: A world-famous phenomenon where the waterfall appears to be on fire under specific sunset conditions in February.
tips: Only accessible for a few weeks in February
Conditions must be just right for the firefall effect to occur

name: Washburn Point
description: A viewpoint on the way to Glacier Point offering spectacular views of Vernal Falls, Half Dome, and Nevada Falls.
tips: Glacier Point Road closes in the winter due to ice and snow

name: Taft Point
description: A dramatic viewpoint featuring steep cliff edges and fissures, accessed via a 2.3-mile round-trip hike.
tips: Be extremely careful near the drop-offs as they are very steep
The hike has an elevation gain of 354 ft
Stay for blue hour for soft light on the granite

name: Half Dome
description: One of the most recognizable rock formations in the park, visible from many different vantage points.
tips: The area outside Curry Village provides spectacular views
The viewing point on Big Oak Flat Road is less busy than other spots

name: Swinging Bridge
description: A bridge crossing the Merced River that provides a vantage point for a beautiful reflection of Upper Yosemite Falls.
tips: Use this vantage point to capture reflections of the falls in the river

name: Superintendent’s Bridge
description: A bridge over the Merced River that serves as both a scenic photography location and a popular swimming spot.
tips: Great for action shots of people swimming or diving into the river
Good location to cool off during the heat of the day

name: Yosemite Falls from Swinging Bridge
description: A great vantage point to capture Yosemite falls, either from the bridge itself or by wandering down the river bank.
tips: A 70-200mm lens is very useful here
In winter, look for hoar frost on the trees after a cold clear night

name: Sentinel Bridge
description: A premier location for capturing the last light of sunset on Half Dome with river reflections.
tips: Expect crowds and many tripods on the bridge
Focus on capturing the reflection of Half Dome in the river

name: Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls Overlook
description: A popular vista from the main hiking path where both falls appear stacked on top of each other.
tips: Stand on a rock and tilt the camera upwards to clear the heads of other visitors in the crowd

name: Cook Meadows Boardwalk
description: A lovely boardwalk trail through a meadow in Yosemite Valley with views of the surrounding granite walls.
tips: You can park right next to the boardwalk for quick access

name: Sentinel Dome
description: A hike that rewards photographers with breathtaking views of El Capitan from a high vantage point.
tips: Park 1 mile before Glacier Point to find the trailhead
Shoot back towards the sun to capture El Capitan from above
Bring a head torch for the hike back in the dark

name: Upper Yosemite Falls
description: A magnificent waterfall visible from many valley locations or via a strenuous hike to the top for views of Half Dome.
tips: Explore pullouts or hike the Yosemite Meadow for different perspectives
The hike to the top is strenuous but provides breathtaking views

name: Sentinel Bridge Parking Area Meadows
description: Meadow area near Sentinel Bridge offering clear views of Yosemite Falls.
tips: Position yourself to capture Yosemite Falls in the background of your shots

name: Valley View
description: A famous sunrise and sunset location that is particularly beautiful after a fresh snowfall in winter.
tips: Ideally shoot after snowfall with mist and breaking sunlight
A tripod is highly recommended
Try blending images if the dynamic range is high

name: Yosemite Falls
description: Comprised of Upper and Lower falls, this is one of the most magnificent features in the valley.
tips: Upper Falls are best shot from near the Ansel Adams gallery
For Lower Falls, shoot with a long lens from the road for natural forest framing

name: Mirror Lake
description: A seasonal lake visible in early spring that offers mirror reflections of Mount Watkins and Half Dome.
tips: Calm days are required for the perfect mirror reflection
Visit in early spring as the water dries up later

name: Bridalveil Falls
description: An iconic waterfall easily accessible via a short path, visible from many valley locations.
tips: The official viewing point is often crowded and offers an awkward angle
Try shooting from the trailhead car park or Tunnel View for better perspective

name: Glacier Point
description: A high-elevation vista providing an eye-level view of Half Dome and incredible stargazing opportunities.
tips: Visit late in August to photograph the Milky Way
The drive into the park takes about an hour to reach this point

name: Tunnel View
description: A classic Yosemite vista showing Bridal Veil Falls, El Capitan, and Half Dome from a single viewpoint.
tips: Located just off Wawona Road next to the tunnel entrance

name: Mariposa Grove
description: A grove of ancient, giant sequoia trees that offers a transportive experience walking among giants.
tips: Allow time for the 2 mile round trip walk among the trees

name: El Capitan
description: A massive rock face and climber's dream that is a showpiece of the National Park.
tips: Visible and photogenic from several locations along Northside and Southside Drive

name: Bridal Veil Fall
description: A spectacular waterfall where photography is best from a distance to capture its full scale.
tips: Shoot from a slight distance along the trail to avoid getting your camera equipment soaked

name: The Cascades
description: A hidden gem waterfall located just outside the western entrance of the park.
tips: Use the designated parking area for easy access to the view

name: The Merced River
description: A river running through the valley that provides excellent opportunities for soft water and long exposure photography.
tips: Look for various access points along Yosemite Valley for intimate and unique compositions
